notes:
1. Strain as Percentage Change

Engineering strain ($\epsilon$) is a dimensionless quantity representing fractional change. It is often useful to express deformation as a percentage change.

$$ \% \text{ Change in Length} = \epsilon \times 100\% = \frac{\Delta L}{L_0} \times 100\% $$
  • Positive % change indicates elongation (tension).
  • Negative % change indicates contraction (compression).

2. Percentage Reduction in Area

In a tensile test, ductility is often measured by the percent reduction in area (%RA) at the point of fracture.

$$ \%RA = \frac{A_0 - A_f}{A_0} \times 100\% $$
  • $A_0$: Original cross-sectional area.
  • $A_f$: Final cross-sectional area at the fracture neck.

3. Volume Change (Volumetric Strain)

The volumetric strain ($\epsilon_v$) represents the percentage change in volume per unit volume. For small strains in an isotropic material:

$$ \epsilon_v = \frac{\Delta V}{V_0} \approx \epsilon_x + \epsilon_y + \epsilon_z $$

Under uniaxial tension (load in x-direction): $\epsilon_x = \epsilon$, $\epsilon_y = -\nu\epsilon$, $\epsilon_z = -\nu\epsilon$.

$$ \epsilon_v = \epsilon (1 - 2\nu) $$

This formula shows that if $\nu = 0.5$, the volumetric strain is zero (constant volume).

solvedExamples.question: A 50 inch bar elongates by 0.1 inches. What is the percentage increase in length?
A cylindrical specimen has an initial diameter of 0.50 in. After fracture, the diameter at the neck is 0.40 in. What is the percent reduction in area?
solvedExamples.explanation: Area is proportional to diameter squared ($A = \pi d^2/4$). Since $\pi/4$ cancels out, the ratio of areas is the ratio of diameters squared. $A_0 \propto 0.50^2 = 0.25$. $A_f \propto 0.40^2 = 0.16$. Percent Reduction = $(0.25 - 0.16) / 0.25 \times 100\% = 0.09 / 0.25 \times 100\% = 36\%$.
